questions.text: A 5-year-old child is crying uncontrollably and is complaining of ear pain. He has a high-grade fever, cold, and nose block. The otoscopic examination showed the following finding. Which of the following organisms is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of severe ear pain, fever, and cold with the otoscopic image showing red and bulging tympanic membrane are likely to be acute suppurative otitis media. Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of this condition. Other organisms that can cause these are:

  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Moraxella catarrhalis
  • Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Clinical features: The child may present with a cold, fever, and earache. If the tympanic membrane ruptures, ear discharge might also be there.

In the stage of presuppuration, there might be a leash of blood vessels that appear along with the handle of the malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane giving it a cart-wheel appearance. Later, the entire tympanic membrane becomes red.

Management:

Since the most common organism responsible are Streptococcus pneumonia and Haemophilus influenza, antibiotics should be started. The effective drugs in acute otitis media are ampicillin (50 mg/kg/day in four divided doses) and amoxicillin (40 mg/kg/day in three divided doses).

Decongestant nasal drops- ephedrine, oxymetazoline, and xylometazoline nasal drops can be used to decrease the edema of the eustachian tube, and promote middle ear ventilation.

Oral nasal decongestants like pseudoephedrine in combination with an antihistamine are effective in treating nasal blockade.

Analgesics and antipyretics are used to relieve pain and fever

If there is ear discharge, it has to be mopped with sterile cotton buds. An antibiotic wick may also be inserted.

Myringotomy: It is incising the eardrum to evacuate pus and is indicated when the drum is bulging and there is acute pain, incomplete resolution despite antibiotics, persistent conductive hearing loss, and persistent effusion beyond 12 weeks.

questions.text: A primigravida presents with lower abdominal pain at 36 weeks of gestation and assumes it to be labor pain. Which of the following statements is incorrect about false labor pain?

choices.text: More commonly experienced by primigravidae than multigravidae
It is associated with the formation of a bag of waters
Pain is relieved by enema and sedation

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about false labor pain is that it is associated with the formation of a bag of waters. True labor pains are associated with the formation of the bag of waters. 

False labor pain is characterized by dull, irregular, and unpredictable pain confined to the lower abdomen and groin. It is not associated with the hardening of the uterus or bag of waters formation and does not cause cervical dilation. Usually, it is relieved with enema or sedatives. It is also known as Braxton Hicks contractions.

It is more common in primigravidae than in parous women and usually appears 1 or 2 weeks prior to the onset of true labor pain in primigravidae and a few days prior in multiparae. 

True labor pain is characterized by pain in the lower abdomen and back, radiating to the thighs. It occurs due to painful uterine contractions at regular intervals with increasing frequency, intensity and duration. It is associated with the show (cervical mucus plug with blood), progressive effacement and dilatation of the cervix and descent of the presenting part. It is not relieved by enema or sedatives.

A bag of waters refers to the lower pole of the fetal membranes containing liquor amnii which bulges into the cervical canal below the presenting part. During uterine contraction, the bag becomes tense and convex due to the rise in intra-amniotic pressure and disappears completely after the contractions. This is almost a certain sign of the onset of true labor.

questions.text: Identify the stage of senile cataract depicted in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic appearance of Morgagnian hypermature cataract.

Morgagnian hypermature cataract is characterized by the liquefaction of the entire cortex. The lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid. The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, its position altering with a change in the position of the head.

Senile Cataract

Types:

  • Cortical (soft cataract): 75%   
  • Nuclear (hard cataract): 25%

Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types.

Cuneiform (70%) Posterior subcapsular/Cupuliform (5%)

Radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrally

Central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex just below the capsule

Late visual loss

Early loss of visual acuity
 

Most visually handicapping senile cataract 

 

Nuclear cataract

  • Pigmented nuclear cataracts: Due to the deposition of urochrome pigment
    • Catarata brunescens
    • Catarata nigra
    • Catarata rubra

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Mental Healthcare Act 2017?

choices.text: Right to access mental health care and treatment
Advance directive by mentally ill persons
Prohibition of electroconvulsive therapy for minors

questions.solution:
Mental Healthcare Act 2017 decriminalized suicide attempts.

The Act states that a person who attempts suicide shall be presumed to be suffering from mental illness at that time and will not be punished under the Indian Penal Code. 

Other important features of Mental Healthcare Act 2017 are as follows:

  • Every person has the right to access mental health care and treatment from services run by the government. These services should be affordable, easily accessible, and of good quality.
  • A mentally ill person has the right to make an advance directive. It states how the person wants to be treated for the illness during a mental health situation and who shall be their nominated representative.
  • Central and State mental health authorities are the administrative bodies to register, supervise, and maintain all mental health establishments.
  • The Mental Health Review Commission and Board will be a quasi-judicial body that reviews the advance directives and advise the government on the protection of the rights of the mentally ill person.
  • Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) can be done only with the use of muscle relaxants and anesthesia. ECT is prohibited for minors. 

 

Related Pearl: The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 and The Mental Health Act, 1987

The Mental Health Care Act, 2017, was passed to provide for health care and services for persons with mental illness and to protect, promote and fulfill their rights during the delivery of mental health care.

Its main provisions are:

  • Patient autonomy: The mentally ill patient has the right to make an advance directive about their treatment and their nominated representative.
  • If the mental health professional/care-giver does not wish to follow the advance directive made by the patient, they can send an application to the Mental Health Board to review/alter/cancel the advance directive.
  • Decriminalization of suicide.
  • Mental Health Review Commission and Mental Health Authority set up.

 

The Mental Health Act, 1987:

The Mental Health Act, 1987 deals with the care of the mentally ill, makes provisions with respect to their property and affairs and states the law for psychiatric hospitals .

Important provisions under it for the diagnosis of mental illness are:

  • For the diagnosis of mental illness, an individual can be kept in a psychiatric hospital for 10 days.
  • If the mental health professional needs further time, the magistrate can permit an extension of 10 more days.
  • This extension can be permitted only twice.
  • Thus, an individual can be detained in a psychiatric hospital for a maximum period of 30 days only.
  • If a mentally ill person is detained against these provisions, the responsible authority can be punished with an imprisonment of upto 2 years.

questions.text: A 4-month-old child was brought with repeated epileptic spasms. The child had reached his normal milestone at the age of 2 months. But the parents noticed that he lost the ability to hold his head steadily and he recently could not track light or sound. What is the finding in the given EEG of this child?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of infantile spasms, developmental regression and the EEG showing hypsarrhythmia is suggestive of West syndrome. 

Hypsarrhythmia is an abnormal interictal pattern that consists of diffuse, high voltage, slow waves with a chaotic background of irregular, multifocal spikes and sharp waves. During the clinical spasm, there is a marked suppression of the EEG background (the electrodecremental response).

Hypsarrhythmias are usually seen in epileptic spasms. These are characterized by a briefly sustained flexion or extension of predominantly proximal muscles, including truncal muscles.

West syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy syndrome that begins in infancy. It is characterized by a triad of:

  • Infantile spasm (also called salaam spells) is a convulsive disease characterized by brief, symmetric axial muscle contraction (neck, trunk, and/or extremities).
  • Developmental regression
  • Hypsarrhythmia (Himalayan wave pattern) on EEG

Treatment of West syndrome includes:

  • ACTH
  • Vigabatrin, if associated with tuberous sclerosis

questions.text: The maximum amount of air that can be expelled from the lungs after first filling the lungs to their maximum extent and then expiring to the maximum extent is equal to ____.
questions.solution:
The maximum amount of air that can be expelled from the lungs after first filling the lungs to their maximum extent and then expiring to the maximum extent is equal to the vital capacity of the lungs.

The vital capacity is the sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume. It is around 4600 mL.

Option A: Functional residual capacity is the sum of expiratory reserve volume and residual volume, and it is the total amount of air remaining in the lungs after normal expiration. It is about 2300 mL.

Option B: The total lung capacity is the maximum volume to which lungs can be expanded with the greatest effort. It is the sum of vital capacity and the residual volume and is about 5800 mL.

Option D: The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level and is about 3500 mL.

questions.text: A man who got involved in a road traffic accident after consuming alcohol is brought to the emergency department. What is the minimum blood alcohol concentration to cause impairment of driving skills?
questions.solution:
The minimum blood alcohol concentration to cause impairment of driving skills is 30-50 mg/dL.

This is the reason that in India, the blood alcohol limit is set at 30 mg/dL, measured by a breathalyzer. Anyone driving over that limit is said to be driving under the influence.

The effects of alcohol intoxication at various blood alcohol concentrations are listed below.

Blood alcohol concentration (mg/dL) Effects 
30-50 Impairment of driving and similar skills
50-100 Reduced inhibitions, slurred speech, laughter
100-150 Incoordination, ataxia
150-200 Obvious drunkenness, nausea, staggering gait
200-300 Vomiting, stupor
300-350 Stupor, coma, risk of aspirating vomitus
350-450 and above Danger of death from respiratory paralysis

questions.text: A male patient presents with a history of back pain. He gives a history of pulling a muscle while lifting heavy weights. On examination, there is exaggerated lumbar lordosis and you perform the test as shown in the image below. Name the test performed.
questions.solution:
Thomas test is being performed in the given image above. 

Thomas test is used to detect fixed flexion deformity of the hip. Here, the affected hip is extended while the contralateral hip is held flexed, flattening and immobilizing the lumbar spine.

Flexion deformity is seen in the initial stages of the disease. The patient keeps the hip in flexion as this is the position of ease and maximum joint capacity. Soft tissue contractures convert this into a fixed flexion deformity, making locomotion impossible.

In an effort to bring the limb on the ground and to make locomotion possible, the lumbar spine undergoes exaggerated lordosis and thus conceals the fixed flexion deformity. This is revealed by the Thomas test. The easy passage of the examiner's hand between the bed and the back of the patient is considered a positive test as normally this is not possible. 

Other options:

Option A: Trendelenburg test is used to assess the weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius muscle. 

Option C: Ober's test is used in physical examination to identify the tightness of the iliotibial band. 

Option D: Allen's test is mainly used to test the adequacy of ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand, which is usually done prior to radial artery cannulation.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man was recently diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the colon. While explaining the pathogenesis of the disease to him, which of the following would you mention as the "first hit" in the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence?

LOH - Loss of heterozygosity
questions.solution:
The mutation of the cancer suppressor gene APC on chromosome 5q21 is the "first hit" in the classical adenoma-carcinoma sequence. 

Adenocarcinoma of the colon is the most common malignancy of the GI tract. The pathogenesis of colon cancer can be explained by three distinct pathways of genomic instability:

  1. Chromosomal instability/APC-β-catenin pathway/Classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence
  2. Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI)
  3. CpG island methylator phenotype pathway.
Chromosomal instability/APC-β-catenin pathway/classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence is the most common pathway, accounting for 80% of sporadic cancers. The "first-hit" in this pathway is the inherited or acquired mutation of the cancer suppressor gene APC on chromosome 5q21. Both copies of the APC gene must be inactivated. The "second hit" is due to methylation abnormalities and inactivation of the normal β-catenin. The loss of the second APC allele follows the "second hit." Mutations of KRAS on chromosome 12p12, TP53 on chromosome 17p13, and LOH at chromosome 18q21 are also involved in further steps of the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence.
 
Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI) occurs in patients with DNA mismatch repair deficiency, leading to the accumulation of mutations in microsatellite repeats. The main pathogenic mechanisms are mutations of type II TGF-β receptor leading to uncontrolled cell growth, and loss of pro-apoptotic BAX which may enhance the survival of genetically abnormal clones.
 
CpG island hypermethylation phenotype (CIMP) - In these tumors, the MLH1 promoter region is typically hypermethylated, thus reducing MLH1 expression and repair function. Activating mutations in the oncogene BRAF are common in these cancers. KRAS and TP53 are not typically mutated. The combination of MSI, BRAF mutation, and methylation of specific targets, such as MLH1, is the signature of this pathway of carcinogenesis.

Related Pearl: Fearon-Vogelstein adenoma-carcinoma multistep model of colorectal neoplasia

questions.text: A patient with renal failure was diagnosed with invasive mucormycosis and was to be started on amphotericin B. Which formulation of amphotericin B would pose the highest risk of nephrotoxicity in him?
questions.solution:
Nephrotoxicity risk is highest with conventional amphotericin B. 

Conventional amphotericin B (C-AMB) is not a lipid-based formulation of amphotericin B. Amphotericin B is insoluble in water, hence C-AMB is formulated by complexing with bile salt deoxycholate to make it suitable for intravenous infusion. Amphotericin deoxycholate is FDA approved for the treatment of mucormycosis but the rationale behind the usage of liposomal amphotericin B over amphotericin deoxycholate in mucormycosis are:

  • Less nephrotoxic than amphotericin B deoxycholate
  • Better CNS penetration than amphotericin B deoxycholate or amphotericin B lipid complex
  • Better outcomes than with amphotericin B deoxycholate 

Nephrotoxicity risk with amphotericin B formulations in decreasing order:

  • C-AMB > Amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC) > Liposomal amphotericin B (L-AMB)
  • All lipid formulations of amphotericin B (ABLC, L-AMB, Amphotericin B colloidal dispersion(ABCD)) are less nephrotoxic than conventional amphotericin B

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with pain during defecation along with the presence of blood-streaked stools. He has had a history of constipation for 5 months. On examination, a sentinel tag is present at the anal orifice. Due to extreme pain, a digital rectal examination is avoided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This case scenario with a history of chronic constipation, and the presence of sentinel tags on examination, suggests a diagnosis of anal fissure.

An anal fissure is a longitudinal split in the anoderm of the distal anal canal. A chronic anal fissure is frequently associated with:

  • Sentinel tag externally
  • Hypertrophied anal papillae internally
  • Anal ulcer overlying the internal sphincter

Anal fissures are usually seen in the young but they can occur at any age with equal sex predilection. Severe pain associated with defecation resolves spontaneously and reappears during the next evacuation. It may even be associated with the passage of fresh blood. 

Most of the fissures are located in the posterior midline followed by the anterior midline. Fissures located anywhere around the anal circumference can be possible due to other diseases like HIV, tuberculosis, syphilis, Crohn's disease, or carcinoma.

Treatment of anal fissure:

  • The focus is to normalize bowel habits. Bowel softeners, dietary fibers, and adequate water should be recommended.
  • Medical therapy involves the topical application of glyceryl trinitrate. It releases nitric oxide and relaxes the internal anal sphincter. This reduces spasms, and pain and improves vasculature to promote healing.
  • Surgical therapy is recommended for chronic fissures that have failed medical therapy. Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice where a portion of the internal sphincter is divided away from the fissure. 

Other options:

Option A: Anal fistula is usually associated with pain and intermittent purulent discharge. On examination, an external opening in the perineum can be found which opens internally in the anal canal.

Option C: Internal hemorrhoids are located proximal to the dentate line. They present with painless bleeding which is separate from the stool, and with a mass near the anal orifice. Pain is not a common feature and is present if hemorrhoids are prolapsed. 

Option D: External hemorrhoids are distal to the dentate line; these may engorge, causing pain. Pain is present throughout the day and is not only associated with defecation or rectal examination. Thrombosis of these external hemorrhoids causes severe pain.

questions.text: The structure marked "?" in the image is composed of _____ cartilage.
questions.solution:
The structure marked "?" in the image is the thyroid cartilage, and it is composed of hyaline cartilage.

Thyroid cartilage is identified by the presence of superior and inferior horns, and its relation with the epiglottis and larynx. The given image shows a cut-open view of the larynx from the back, and here, the thyroid cartilage encases the larynx anteriorly. The stalk of the epiglottis is also seen attached to the inner surface of the thyroid cartilage.

Hyaline cartilage is made up of chondrocytes and matrix:

  • The chondrocytes in the deeper matrix are rounded in shape and may appear in groups of eight that originate from the mitotic divisions of a single chondroblast. These groups of cells are called isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests.
  • The important components of the matrix are type II collagen, aggrecan (proteoglycan), and chondronectin (glycoprotein).
  • The matrix that immediately surrounds the chondrocytes is basophilic and is known as the territorial matrix, whereas the matrix that is more distant from the cells appears pale and is known as the interterritorial matrix.

Hyaline cartilage is found at various sites:

  • Larger respiratory passages (nose, larynx, trachea, and bronchi)
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Cricoid cartilage
  • Base of the arytenoid cartilage
  • Ventral end of ribs, where they articulate with the sternum
  • Epiphyseal plate of long bones
  • Articular cartilage of synovial joints 
  • Temporary skeleton in embryo

On microscopy, hyaline cartilage can be identified by the following characteristics:

  • Presence of chondrocytes within lacunae.
  • Group of two or more chondrocytes, which are known as isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests
  • Basophilic territorial matrix and pale interterritorial matrix
  • Presence of perichondrium with outer fibrous and the inner cellular layer

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents for advice regarding obesity. On multiple occasions over the past 4 months, she has eaten large amounts of food at night and felt disgusted, and guilty after. She is distressed about overeating but states that she can not control it. There is no history of vomiting. Her BMI is 35. Which of the following disorders is responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with a patient having recurrent episodes of uncontrollable binge eating for over 3 months, associated with distress and feelings of guilt in the absence of inappropriate compensatory behavior such as vomiting, is suggestive of binge-eating disorder. It is described as the consumption of unusually large amounts of food over a short period. People with this condition feel that they have no control over their eating. They are also concerned about their weight and eating habits. It is the most common eating disorder.

DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Binge-eating disorder:

A. Recurrent episodes of binge eating. An episode of binge eating is characterized by both the following:

1. Eating, in a discrete period, an amount of food that is larger than what most people would eat in a similar period under similar circumstances.

2. A sense of lack of control over eating during the episode (e.g., a feeling that one cannot stop eating or control what or how much one is eating).

B. The binge-eating episodes are associated with

1. Eating much more rapidly than normal.

2. Eating until feeling uncomfortably full.

3. Eating large amounts of food when not feeling physically hungry.

4. Eating alone because of feeling embarrassed by how much one is eating.

5. Feeling disgusted with oneself, depressed, or very guilty afterward.

C. Marked distress regarding binge eating is present.

D. The binge-eating occurs, on average, at least once a week for 3 months.

E. Binge eating is not associated with the recurrent use of inappropriate compensatory behavior as in bulimia nervosa and does not occur exclusively during bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa.

 

Other options:

Bulimia nervosa: People with bulimia nervosa perform compensatory behavior such as vomiting, laxative abuse, or excessive dieting after binge eating. The person maintains a normal BMI.

Night eating disorder: It is characterized by a large amount of food consumption after an evening meal. They generally have a little appetite during the day and suffer from insomnia. They are not overly concerned with their body image and weight and the amount of food consumed is lower than binge eating done in bulimia and binge eating disorders.

Anorexia nervosa: People with Anorexia nervosa are underweight and have an excessive drive for thinness and intense fear of gaining weight.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is rushed to the emergency department after having choked on a bone while eating. He is responsive but unable to speak. What is to be done next?
questions.solution:
In a choking child (more than 1 year old) or an adult, the first step to be done is to perform Heimlich maneuver which involves delivering abdominal thrusts.

The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient’s waist. A fist is made with one hand and using the other hand, the fist is driven into the patient’s abdomen with a rapid, forceful upward thrust so as to dislodge the foreign body. This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

 In a choking infant who is responsive, 5 back slaps between the shoulder blades and 5 downward thrusts on the chest are given in order to dislodge the foreign body.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of fever, cough, and hemoptysis for a few weeks. On staining his sputum, gram-negative bacilli with the typical safety pin appearance were identified. Culture on Ashdown medium showed wrinkled, purple colonies. Which of the following could be the possible causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of the patient, detection of gram-negative bacilli with safety pin appearance, and formation of wrinkled, purple colonies on culture are together suggestive of Whitmore's disease or melioidosis caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei.

Infection with B. pseudomallei is acquired by contamination of abrasion wounds with soil and water containing the bacilli. Patients with underlying diseases like diabetes mellitus have an increased risk of acquiring the infection.

Melioidosis can be of two types:

  • Acute - It causes acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates or severe necrotizing disease. It can also mimic tuberculosis with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. It may lead to septicemia. Acute cases have a high case fatality rate. 
  • Chronic - It can lead to the development of multiple caseous or suppurative foci, with skin and subcutaneous abscesses. These can lead to lymphangitis and lymphadenopathy. It may involve bones and other internal organs.

On microscopy, small, irregularly staining gram-negative bacilli can be demonstrated for diagnosis. Methylene blue stain shows a typical bipolar safety pin appearance. ELISA for IgM and IgG antibodies and indirect hemagglutination can be also used for diagnosis. 

Treatment is divided into two stages: an intensive phase of 2 weeks of therapy with ceftazidime (drug of choice) or a carbapenem, followed by 12 weeks of oral cotrimoxazole to eradicate the organism and prevent relapse.

The image below shows dry purple wrinkled colonies of B. pseudomallei cultured in Ashdown medium. 

Option B: Burkholderia mallei causes glanders disease. It is a gram-negative, irregularly staining bacillus with a beaded appearance. It is usually an equine infection. Human infection is possible and is usually occupational, found among veterinarians and persons working with/caring for horses. Acute infection presents with fever, mucopurulent nasal discharge, and severe prostration.

Option C: Burkholderia cepacia is an opportunist pathogen, usually seen in cases of cystic fibrosis or chronic granulomatous disease. It causes a rapidly fatal syndrome of respiratory distress and septicemia (cepacia syndrome) in cystic fibrosis patients.

Option D: Paraburkholderia species do not cause human infection. They are beneficial to plants.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the hospital with the following skin lesions on both legs. Which of the following appearances of deposits do you expect to see at the dermo-epidermal junction on the direct immunofluorescence test?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 5-year-old child with the lesions shown in the given image having a string of pearls or cluster of jewels sign is characteristic of linear IgA disease, with linear deposits of IgA at the dermo-epidermal junction.

Linear IgA disease/ chronic bullous disorder of childhood (CBDC) is an immunobullous disease of childhood that clinically can present as an annular arrangement of vesicles. It arises more abruptly in children compared to adults. It has a bimodal onset, below the age of 5 years and between the age of 60 - 65 years.

Clinical features include:

  • Mucous membrane lesions like oral erosions and ulcers are commonly seen. Nasal crusting and genital lesions may also occur.
  • Tense blisters, vesicles, and annular erythema are the characteristic triad of clinical features.
  • The blisters are arranged in a circular fashion, resembling a crown/ cluster of jewels or a string of pearls appearance.
  • In young children, the distribution of lesions is perioral, perianal, and perineum.
  • In adults, the distribution is over the extensors and the trunk.

Note: The string of pearls or cluster of jewels sign is characteristic of linear IgA disease and not pathognomic of this disease. 

The image below shows a string of pearls appearance in the Linear IgA disease.

Precipitating factors include:

  • Infections
  • Trauma
  • Vaccination
  • UV radiation exposure
  • Drugs like:
    • Vancomycin
    • Penicillin
    • NSAIDs

The main target antigens in this disease are BP180 and BPAg2 much more than BP230 or BPAg1.The mechanism of blister formation is due to the subepidermal splitting and neutrophilic infiltrate in the papillary dermis forming microabscesses. 

The image given below shows subepidermal blister formation and neutrophilic infiltrate in the papillary dermis.

The diagnostic hallmark is the linear deposition of IgA deposits at DEJ identified by direct immunofluorescence.

Management involves:

  • First line:
    • Dapsone
    • Topical steroids with or without prednisolone
  • Second line:
    • Sulfa drugs like Sulfapyridine/ sulphamethoxypyridazine are alternatives for dapsone
    • Anti‐inflammatory antibiotics like oxytetracycline, doxycycline with or without nicotinamide
  • Third line:
    • Mycophenolate
    • IVIG
    • Immunoadsorption

Other options:

Fish-net appearance at the dermo-epidermal junction is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris and foliaceous.

The speckled appearance of direct immunofluorescence is seen in systemic lupus erythematosus.

Focal granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae are seen in dermatitis herpetiformis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the casualty department with bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremors. His attender reported that he had been diagnosed with schizophrenia and had recently started treatment.  What is the drug of choice to treat the patient's presenting symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced parkinsonism, for which the drug of choice is benzhexol, also known as trihexiphenidyl. 

Drug-induced parkinsonism is caused by certain drugs that have D2 antagonistic action, such as typical antipsychotics. Due to the decrease in dopaminergic activity, they result in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Benzhexol is a centrally acting antimuscarinic agent. It acts by restoring the cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons.

The following drugs are implicated in drug-induced parkinsonism:

questions.text: A 20-year-old bodybuilder started a diet of raw eggs as a source of protein, following which he developed dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, and muscular pains. On investigation, he was diagnosed with a vitamin deficiency. Which of the following enzymes does not require this vitamin as a coenzyme?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of features like dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, and muscle pain developing in an individual on a raw egg diet is suggestive of biotin deficiency, and carbamoyl phosphate synthetase is the enzyme that is not dependent on biotin.

A protein called avidin is present in the egg white, which binds to biotin in the diet, making biotin unavailable for intestinal absorption. Avidin is heat labile, and boiling of the egg neutralizes its inhibitory activity. One molecule of avidin can bind with four molecules of biotin.

Biotin deficiency is rare, except in individuals on prolonged total parenteral nutrition and those consuming raw eggs. Individuals with a biotin deficiency may develop features such as dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, hyperesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, and hallucinations. Treatment is the administration of an injection of 100–300 mg biotin.

Biotin serves as a co-enzyme for several carboxylase enzymes:

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase
    • This enzyme adds CO2 to acetyl CoA, forming malonyl CoA.
    • It is the rate-limiting reaction in the biosynthesis of fatty acids
  • Pyruvate carboxylase
    • Pyruvate + CO2 +ATP → Oxaloacetate +ADP + Pi
    • It provides oxaloacetate, which is the catalyst for the TCA cycle and is an important enzyme in gluconeogenesis.
  • Propionyl CoA carboxylase
    • Propionyl CoA +CO2 + ATP → Methyl malonyl CoA + ADP + Pi
  • Methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase

Biotin also plays a role in the regulation of the cell cycle.

Biotin-independent reactions:

  • Urea and pyrimidine synthesis, with carbamoyl phosphate synthetase as the stepping stone
  • Addition of CO2 to form C6 in the purine ring
  • Conversion of pyruvate to malate by malic enzyme

questions.text: Identify the structure marked "A" in the CT scan of the thorax shown below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked "A" in the CT Thorax is the ascending aorta.

In a CT study, X-rays are applied in a circular motion and body tissue slices are recreated mathematically. Different tissues are seen with different intensities, depending on the proportion of attenuation of the X-rays that pass through them.

  • Air and water are displayed as low-intensity (dark appearance) areas because they produce only little attenuation.
  • Bone is displayed as a high-intensity structure (bright appearance) because of its significant attenuation.
  • High density is seen in the presence of hyperemia, freshly clotted blood, and contrast agents.
  • Edema and necrosis are seen as low-intensity areas.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male patient presents with fever and right lower quadrant pain. On examination, there is tenderness and guarding with an ill-defined mass in the right iliac fossa. A CT scan shows an appendicolith and a complete blood count reveals leucocytosis. The patient improves on conservative treatment. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Wait and watch for spontaneous resolution

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of appendicular mass. Interval appendectomy is done after the conservative management of an appendicular mass with appendicolith.

Clinically, patients with the appendicular mass present with a mass in the right iliac fossa, fever, abdominal pain, and increased pulse rate. In appendicular mass, the inflammatory process is already localized and any surgical intervention may be difficult and dangerous. 

Hence, if the general condition is satisfactory, the conservative Ochsner–Sherren regimen is used. After conservative management, a CT scan follow-up should be done to check for complete resolution of the mass.

Following successful management of appendicular mass, removal of the appendix is advised by a procedure called interval appendectomy in 6-8 weeks after conservative management. The rationale for interval appendectomy is to prevent recurrent appendicitis and risks associated with emergent appendectomy or perforation of the appendix.

Interval appendectomy is reserved in:

  • Recurrent appendicitis
  • Appendicolith (leads to recurrent appendicitis)
  • Children

Other options:

Option A: Immediate appendectomy after conservative management has an overall higher rate of complications, wound infections, and abdominal/pelvic abscess formation. So it is better to be avoided.

Option C: Percutaneous drainage is to be done when pelvic abscess and appendicular abscess do not resolve with conservative management.

Option D: Appendicolith increases inflammation and leads to recurrent attacks of appendicitis. Hence it is not advisable to wait and watch for its spontaneous resolution.

Related Pearl: Oshner Sherren Regimen

Principle :

  • The inflammatory process is already localised and that inadvertent surgery is difficult and may be dangerous.
  • It may be impossible to find the appendix and, occasionally, a faecal fistula may form.
  • Antibiotic therapy should be given after performing CECT abdomen
  • Abscess if present can be drained radiologically.

Outcome :

  • Improvement in 24–48 h
  • 90% cases resolve
  • Failure should raise suspicion of Crohn’s disease and carcinoma. 

Criteria for stopping conservative treatment of Appendicular mass:

  • Rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain
  • Increasing size of the mass
